content.title: The Sustainable Energy Academy
content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1

content.text: The Sustainable Energy Academy is a training and knowledge-exchange mechanism developed by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) to support the transition to sustainable energy worldwide. This lesson describes the Academy's Objectives, Target Learners, Core Content and Programme Strategy.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: energy moonshot
concepts.body: An energy moonshot refers to an ambitious, large-scale initiative aimed at achieving a breakthrough in energy technology or sustainability, often with the goal of significantly reducing carbon emissions or enhancing energy efficiency.

concepts.title: the undp sustainable energy hub
concepts.body: The UNDP Sustainable Energy Hub is a platform created by the United Nations Development Programme to promote sustainable energy solutions, facilitate knowledge sharing, and support countries in achieving their energy-related goals, particularly in the context of sustainable development and climate action.

content.text: The Sustainable Energy Academy aims to create concrete impact on the ground by providing countries with tailor-made capacity building and a strong global community of experts and practitioners on energy as an enabler for development. The Academy will connect energy for development with nexus topics such as social protection and employment, policy and governance, climate change, energy security, gender equality, finance, technology and data, water management and food resilience. Through this initiative, UNDP Sustainable Energy Hub seeks to contribute to the achievement of the 2022-2025 UNDP Strategic Plan’s moonshot to support 500 million people in accessing clean, sustainable, and affordable energy and to accelerate the energy transition.

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Objectives

content.text: Shape the narrative of energy as an enabler for development The Energy Academy plays a crucial role in reshaping the narrative surrounding energy by highlighting its potential as a catalyst for sustainable development. By integrating energy with various sectors such as social protection, health, gender equality, governance, digital, finance and climate adaptation and mitigation, we aim to emphasize the transformative power of renewable energy solutions in addressing complex development challenges. Position energy as an essential topic in development-centered discussions Through the Sustainable Energy Academy, we aim to position energy at the forefront of development-centered discussions, particularly within the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) framework. By raising awareness and promoting dialogue on the importance of sustainable energy, UNDP seeks to influence policy and decision-making processes at both national and international levels.

Prepare governments on energy solutions, trends, challenges, and opportunities The Energy Academy aims to provide countries with the necessary knowledge, skills, and resources to effectively implement energy solutions. By equipping relevant stakeholders, including UNDP staff, local and national governments, civil society, with the expertise to advocate for sustainable energy solutions, they can more effectively influence policy formulation and promote the adoption of innovative approaches to energy planning and implementation. Create an interactive platform for technical knowledge and expertise sharing The Energy Academy aims to serve as a vibrant and collaborative platform for technical knowledge and expertise sharing among countries. Through interactive modules, live webinars, discussion forums, and resource libraries, policymakers, government officials, and stakeholders will have access to a wealth of information, best practices, and case studies. This collaborative environment aims to foster cross-learning, facilitate peer-to-peer exchanges, and strengthen countries’ collective capacity to address energy-related challenges.

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Target Audience

content.text: The Sustainable Energy Academy is not limited to technical experts; it actively engages young people and diverse demographics. Recognizing the cross-cutting nature of energy issues, the Sustainable Energy Academy also aims to engage stakeholders from diverse sectors such as health, social policy and gender equality, climate change, digital and data, governance, and finance. By fostering interdisciplinary collaboration and knowledge exchange, we seek to address the complex interactions between energy and these interconnected sectors, ensuring a holistic and integrated approach to sustainable development.

content.intro: M1: Introduction to Sustainable Energy System Transformation | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Program Strategy: How the Energy Academy Works

content.text: The Sustainable Energy Academy offer is framed around three key services: Learning and Training; Building a Community and Exchanging Knowledge; and Facilitating Engagements. This three-tiered approach emulates the UNDP’s SURGE Academy* and the SDG Finance Academy**, which have both been proven to be successful. Learning is no longer only delivered online and one-off training is not seen as sufficient to achieve learning outcomes. Instead, it requires ongoing delivery over a more extended period, community engagement, learning from other people and experiences, and clear use of case studies for application, as well as continual updating and adjusting. * The SURGE Academy learning path prepares expert UNDP staff for rapid response deployments to country offices in the immediate aftermath of disaster, conflict, or shock. ** The SDG Finance Academy brings UNDP’s sustainable finance knowledge to the world by building a community of experts to join in marshaling public and private finance for the SDGs.
